hosts : all
tasks :
  - name : add crontab test entry
    cron :
      name  : crontab test
      job   : echo 'Testing!' > /var/log/crontest.log
      state : present

hosts : all
tasks :
  - name  : remove user's crontab
    shell : crontab -r

so_45275631: find dir1 dir2 ... -type f -size 0 -print | xargs rm

xargs(1)

find dir1 dir2 ... -type f -size 0 -print | grep 'someRegularExpression' | xargs rm

find dir1 dir2 ... -type f -size 0 -print | grep 'someRegularExpression' | tee erased.txt | xargs rm

Explanations about Options.-0:
Input items are terminated by a null character instead of by whitespace, and the
 quotes and backslash are not special (every character is taken literally).
 Disables the end of file string, which is treated like any other argument. Useful
 when input items might contain white space, quote marks, or backslashes. The GNU
 find -print0 option produces input suitable for this mode.

Explanations about Options.-q:
Quiet; produces output suitable for logging, omitting progress indicators. More q's
 will produce more quiet up to a maximum of 2. You can also use -q=# to set the quiet
 level, overriding the configuration file. Note that quiet level 2 implies -y; you
 should never use -qq without a no-action modifier such as -d, --print-uris or -s as
 APT may decide to do something you did not expect. Configuration Item: quiet.
Explanations about Options.--yes:
Automatic yes to prompts; assume "yes" as answer to all prompts and run
 non-interactively. If an undesirable situation, such as changing a held package,
 trying to install an unauthenticated package or removing an essential package occurs
 then apt-get will abort. Configuration Item: APT::Get::Assume-Yes.
Explanations about Options.-o:
Set a Configuration Option; This will set an arbitrary configuration option. The
 syntax is -o Foo::Bar=bar. -o and --option can be used multiple times to set
 different options.
